resource.name: Crown Land
resource.description:
A spatial dataset of all Crown lands in Nova Scotia. Crown lands are all or any part of the land under the administration and control of the Minister of Natural Resources and Renewables as per the Crown Lands Act. The dataset includes land in which the Nova Scotia Department of Natural Resources and Renewables has full or partial interest.
Data download also available via GeoNova: https://nsgi.novascotia.ca/WSF_DDS/DDS.svc/DownloadFile?tkey=fhrTtdnDvfytwLz6&id=87
Map service view also available via GeoNova: https://www.arcgis.com/home/webmap/viewer.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fnsgiwa.novascotia.ca%2Farcgis%2Frest%2Fservices%2FPLAN%2FPLANCrownLandsWM84V1%2FMapServer&source=sd

resource.name: Municipal Property Tax Rates
resource.description: The dataset is a list of property tax rates that are applicable in each municipality in the Province. These rates are applied to property assessment (based on market value) which can change from year to year. The convention is to express the tax rate as per $100 of assessment e.g., Amherst's residential rate is $1.63 per $100 of assessment.

domain_metadata.value: This information has been gathered from Statement of Estimate Reports as submitted to the Province by municipalities. The municipalities are required to submit this information to the Province by September 30th of each year.  Municipalities may also have additional area rates for special services on top of the general rate. Users are cautioned these tax rates are for general reference only, for official rates please contact the appropriate Municipality.   The Cape Breton Suburban rate is an average of 8 various rural suburban tax rates within the county of Cape Breton.    Effective April 1st, 2020, the Town of Windsor and the Municipality of West Hants have consolidated into a regional municipality, West Hants Regional Municipality. Please note, that the data for the West Hants Regional Municipality/Windsor/Hantsport  2020/2021 to 2022/2023 were amended on 2024-02-21.
Annually from each fiscal year, from 2009/2010 to 2024/2024 (April 1, 2009 to March 31, 2024)

resource.description:
*Please note that this data is now outdated, as climate modeling methods have improved since CMIP3. Users seeking updated climate projections for Nova Scotia can find this data at: https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/NS-Climate-Change-Projections-CMIP5-/r7d9-j7wx

Climate data for regions of Nova Scotia. Each region has historical data for a 30 year baseline period (1961 – 90) and future projections out to the end of the century (2100).

domain_metadata.value: *Please note that this data is now outdated, as climate modeling methods have improved since CMIP3. Users seeking updated climate projections for Nova Scotia can find this data at: https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/NS-Climate-Change-Projections-CMIP5-/r7d9-j7wx Future projections are based on 30 year time periods: 2020s (2011 – 2040), 2050s (2041 – 2070) and 2080s (2071 – 2100). This information was generated by the Meteorological Service of Canada at Environment Canada and uses a statistical downscaling method based on the Canadian Global Climate Model (CGCM1). Data was collected in 2011.

resource.name: Digital Animation Tax Credit – Approved Tax Credits
resource.description: Public record for the Digital Animation Tax Credit containing information from approved Part A and Part B applications across all corporations. Information includes company name, parent company name, production title, application type (Part A or B), amount of credit approved (or sought if Part A) and approval date.
columns_name:
Amount of Credit Provided 
(or Sought if Part A)

domain_metadata.value: Part A and Part B applications are both mandatory. Productions are added to the list after a Part A / Part B application is approved.  A Part A application determines whether a production is eligible for the tax credit and uses the production's budget to calculate an estimated tax credit amount the corporation may receive. A Part B application determines whether a production continues to meet the eligibility criteria and uses actual spending to calculate a tax credit amount. Once a Part B application is approved, a tax credit certificate is issued and the corporation can claim the tax credit on their corporate income tax return.

resource.name: Native Language of Nominees
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Nominees must demonstrate proficiency in English or French in order to be eligible for nomination, but they often have a native language that is neither English nor French. This dataset provides the the number of certificates issued annually by the native language of the nominees.

The maximum number of nomination certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of February 3, 2023. While nominees must be proficient in English or French, they may be accompanied by a spouse or dependents who are not yet proficient in English or French.

resource.description: The well-water Nitrate Monitoring Program was a long-term study that involved annual testing for groundwater nitrate from 1989-2012 at approximately 150 wells in Kings County, NS, which is one of the most intensely farmed areas of the province.

resource.name: Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network Continuous Water Quality Data
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Automated Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network was established in 2002 to assess water quality in surface waters across the province at five stations (and one discontinued station, St Mary's River).  The results are used to help manage water resources, determine baseline water quality in lakes and watercourses throughout the province, evaluate the impact of human activities on surface water, and assess long term trends in water quality.

The following weblink connects to a Nova Scotia Environment web map that includes the six monitoring station locations within the province and an alternative method for downloading the same datasets: http://nse.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=7ded7a30bef44f848e8a4fc8672c89bd

domain_metadata.value: The data is measurements collected on an hourly timestep using Hydrolab water quality instruments at five stations: Pockwock Lake (NS01EH0050), Shelburne River (NS01ED9111), Northeast Margaree River (NS01FB0001), Kelley River (NS01DL0009) and LaHave River (NS01EF0002). Data for the discontinued St Mary's River (NS01EO0001) site is for the 2007 to 2008 time period. The measured water quality parameters are the following: temperature (°C), pH (-), conductivity (µS/cm), dissolved oxygen (mg/L) and turbidity (NTU).  Five of the stations are located on watercourses and co-located with Water Survey of Canada hydrometric stations.  Most stations have had quarterly water quality samples collected and submitted for laboratory analysis as part of the grab sample program in various years for the monitoring period. From 2019 onward, only Pockwock Lake, Shelburne River and Kelley River continue to have quarterly water quality sampling performed by the Department. Environment and Climate Change Canada performs periodic water quality sampling on the remaining stations.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Topographic Database - Land Cover (Line Layer)
resource.description:
Part of the Nova Scotia Topographic Database (NSTDB), the land cover theme layer is updated and maintained from aerial photography. Land cover is limited to treed areas over 3600m2 in size and over two metres in height. Orchards, nurseries, tree lines, and single landmark trees are also included. Land Cover feature codes and their descriptions are provided with the download in a NSTDB feature code table.

resource.name: Long-term Care Waitlist
resource.description: Number of individuals waiting for Long-term Care placement - weekly

domain_metadata.value: Current as of February 2, 2024. The number of people who are awaiting initial placement in a Long-term Care (LTC) facility are separated and reported into two categories: those who are currently waiting within the community and those who are waiting and are currently in hospital.  The sum of these two categories can be found in the dataset column labeled Total Waiting for Initial Placement.  There is a separate waitlist column for those LTC residents who are placed currently within a LTC facility but are awaiting a placement in a different LTC facility, this waitlist can be found in the dataset column labeled Waiting for Inter-Facility Transfer. To ensure greater clarity, the previously labeled Total column has been removed.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Assessment Results by Year and Board - Mathématiques en 4e année
resource.description: Provides assessment results for Mathematics (scaled score and performance level) for each year assessment has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the assessments.

domain_metadata.value: French program (CSAP) Grade 4 students write this assessment in late September/early October. Students answered questions in each of the mathematics strands (le nombre; les régularités et les relations; la mesure et la géométrie; et les statistiques et les probabilités). Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) and Level 4 (above the expectation).Students also received a scaled score in mathematics (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800).  Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to develop this assessment and to set the performance expectation, which is what students should know and be able to do on their own at the beginning of grade 4. As of April 1, 2018, Nova Scotia Regional School Boards became Regional Centres for Education (RCE). Geographical areas for regional centres and their historical school boards can be found here: https://novascotia.ca/just/regulations/regs/edregcen.htm . The Conseil scolaire acadien provincial (CSAP) remained the same.

resource.name: Central Line Associated Bloodstream Infection (CLABSI) Rates in Intensive Care Units (ICU)
resource.description: Central line associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI) rates are measured and monitored by infection prevention and control staff as a means to evaluate the effectiveness of their infection control protocols. CLABSI rates are calculated by dividing the number of central line bloodstream infections by the total number of days in which patients had a central line in the ICU in each reporting period. The rate is reported per 1,000 patient line days. The Canadian benchmark for each type of intensive care units (Adult, Neonatal, Pediatric) are included in the dataset. Data fields include: Year, Quarter, Category, Health Authority, Health Authority Zone, Canadian benchmark, CLABSI rate

domain_metadata.value: Quarterly data each span 3 months. (Q1  April - June, Q2 July - Sept, Q3 Oct - Dec, and Q4 Jan - Mar). NSHA reported data is broken into its 4 management zones. Provincial reported data comprises of the 4 NSHA management zones and the IWK. October to December 2022 data is incomplete for Central and Provincial Rate so the cells are blank.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations
resource.description:
Locations of sampling stations for sensor strings deployed as part of the Centre for Marine Applied Research's (CMAR) Coastal Monitoring Program. Sensor strings record high-resolution temperature, dissolved oxygen, and intermittent salinity data at various depths, typically for several months. 

The dataset for each county is available at https://data.novascotia.ca/browse?Detailed-Metadata_Department=Fisheries+and+Aquaculture&tags=coastal+monitoring+program

For more information on CMAR and the Coastal Monitoring Program go to: https://cmar.ca/reports/
columns_description: approximate longitude of the station
approximate latitude of the station
area where at least one string has been deployed
waterbody in which the station is located
county in which the station is located

domain_metadata.value: Coastal Monitoring Program: County datasets and visualizations https://data.novascotia.ca/browse?Detailed-Metadata_Department=Fisheries+and+Aquaculture&tags=coastal+monitoring+program and Coastal Monitoring County reports https://cmar.ca/reports/

This dataset is complementary to the Coastal Monitoring Program county datasets available on the Open Data Portal. It indicates the approximate location of stations with  data available for download from the portal. Station coordinates are approximate because exact deployment coordinates change each time an installation is serviced. For exact deployment locations, see the corresponding county dataset. The Station Locations dataset contains the following columns:  COUNTY: county in which the station is located. WATERBODY: waterbody in which the station is located. STATION: area where at least one string has been deployed. LATITUDE: approximate latitude of the station. LONGITUDE: approximate longitude of the station.

resource.name: Mortality Mapping by the NS Medical Examiner Service
resource.description: Rates of specific causes or types of death by geographic area
columns_description: Rate per 100,000 population is within this range
Number of cases per 100,000 population using Statistics Canada census population estimates; Crude rate per 100,000 population

Manner of death refers to the mode of method of death and is classified as one of five manners: natural; accident; suicide; homicide; undetermined (https://nslegislature.ca/sites/default/files/legc/statutes/fatality%20investigations.pdf). Acute toxicity deaths are not classified as natural in manner and therefore this dataset excludes deaths for which manner was classified as natural.
County of Residence
Mortality Type
5 year time period

domain_metadata.value: Data are current as of June 28, 2022. Data are extracted from a live database environment and are provisional and subject to change. Some case investigations in recent years remain ongoing. Data here include confirmed toxicity deaths for all years six probable toxicity deaths in 2021 with investigation ongoing. Probable drug toxicity deaths will either become confirmed cases once cause of death is certified, or will be determined to not be a toxicity death (death from another cause) and removed from these counts in future data releases. 'All manners' category includes deaths where manner was classified as either accident, suicide, or undetermined. (Acute toxicity deaths are not classified as natural in manner of death, and no toxicity deaths were classified as homicide.) Data reflect cause and manner of death recorded on death certificate. Population data have been updated with the most recent available data from Statistics Canada (98-401-X2021004; rate data may differ slightly from previous releases). County populations in 2016 and 2021 were used for 2012-2016 and 2017-2021 mean rate calculations, respectively.   Data includes deaths caused by acute toxicity following administration of exogenous substance(s), including pharmaceutical and nonpharmaceutical drugs and alcohol. Excludes: gases and inhalants, death due to medical consequences of long term substance use, medical assistance in dying, trauma with substances detected but not involved in the mechanism of death. NS totals may be greater than sum of health zones as totals include cases where location of residence was out of province. Totals will also be greater than the sum of accident and suicide where cases remain under investigation and/or manner was certified as 'undetermined'. Data for substances are not mutually exclusive as some deaths are due to toxicity from multiple substances, which may act synergistically to cause death (and may or may not have reached lethal levels alone). As such, counts of deaths by substance cannot be added together for meaningful sums. See the ‘All substances’ category for overall counts of unique deaths and associated rates.    This dataset includes the following categories for drug type: total – all substances, opioid. Drug-specific data rely on toxicology findings which have a typical lag of 2-8 weeks.  See related dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/Health-and-Wellness/Numbers-and-rates-of-substance-related-fatalities-/iu6y-z4n3) for more details on methods.

resource.name: Industry Specialization based on Business Locations by Functional Economic Regions
resource.description: The dataset provides information on industry specialization, industry structure and number of business locations for Nova Scotia’s Functional Economic Regions.  The data fields include: Functional Economic Region Name, Month and Year; Category (e.g., Farming); Type (Traded or Local); North American Industry Classification (NAICS) - 6-digits; Location Quotient based on Business Locations; and Employment Size Categories for Business Locations.  Fields may be added to or change over time.
columns_name: Location Quotient based on Business Locations
North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) Title

domain_metadata.value: (Click the "Show More" link below for the list of attached reports) Industry specialization can be measured using Location Quotients (LQ) that compare the regional share of businesses in an industry with the national share of businesses in the same industry. An LQ greater than 1 suggests the number of businesses in an industry is more concentrated in the region than it is nationally. An LQ greater than 2 indicates a very high level of specialization or concentration, 1.25 to 2 indicates a high specialization; an LQ close to 1 (0.75-1.25) indicates an average specialization; and less than 0.75 indicates a low specialization. An LQ of 0 for a particular industry means that no businesses in that particular industry exists in the region.
December 2014, December 2018,  June 2019, June 2020, for December 2020, June 2021 and December 2021

resource.name: Halifax County Current Data
resource.description: Current speed and direction time series data collected in a vertical profile at various locations throughout the coastal waters of Halifax County.
columns_description: direction of water flow for corresponding depth bin and timestamp (degrees). Measured travelling away from the ADCP sensor relative to True North (a reading of 90 degrees describes current travelling from west to east).

distance from the surface to the centre of the measurement bin (metres). Calculated as sensor_depth_below_surface_m + sensor_height_above_sea_floor_m - bin_height_above_sea_floor_m. See “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) for sensor_height_above_sea_floor_m.

timestamp of the start of the ensemble (in UTC). Current speed and direction recorded at each timestamp are an average of many measurements recoded during the ensemble. See the “Nova Scotia Current Data Deployment Information” dataset for ensemble details for each deployment.
specific area where ADCP was deployed.
waterbody in which the ADCP was deployed.

unique identifier for ADCP deployment. IDs are assigned incrementally by deployment date within a county. A skipped ID (e.g., consecutive IDs are XY001 and XY003) indicates that an ADCP was deployed but no useable current data were recovered (e.g., the battery failed).
water speed for corresponding depth bin and timestamp (m / s).
the depth of the ADCP below the surface (metres), measured by the ADCP sensor. Changes with the tide.
distance from the seafloor to the centre of the measurement bin (metres).

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) coordinates an extensive Coastal Monitoring Program to measure essential ocean variables (EOVs) throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters. This dataset includes data from the Current branch of the program. Data from the Water Quality and Wave branches of the program are also available on the Nova Scotia Open Data Portal. CMAR has worked with the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) and marine service providers to measure ocean current at various locations in Nova Scotia since 2007. The data is collected with Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) deployed on the seafloor. An ADCP is a hydroacoustic current meter that measures water velocities over a range of depths. These sensors measure soundwaves scattered back from moving particles in the water column and use the Doppler effect to estimate speed and direction.  Current data is organized by county. Each county dataset includes data from multiple ADCP deployments that vary in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when analyzing the data. The “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) summarises the specifications of each deployment. Individual deployments are identified in the county dataset and metadata by a unique ID in the deployment_id column.   The county datasets are large and can exceed the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the waterbody, station, and/or deployment_id of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/364r-tvmi).   Current data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha). Summary reports for each county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. Data have been trimmed of side-lobe interference. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. CMAR recommends users apply additional quality control prior to using the data. If you have accessed any of the Current data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

resource.name: Tourism Accommodations Real Property Tax Rebate Program (TARPTR)
resource.description: The Tourism Accommodations Real Property Tax Rebate Program provides qualified operators a 25 per cent rebate on payment of 2020-21 commercial property tax. To be eligible, a business must meet the definition of a roofed accommodation as set out in the Tourist Accommodation Registration Act, be registered as a host under the act, have more than five rooms and have paid their tax bill in full.

domain_metadata.value: Definitions: Yes: business applied and received TARPTR funding; No: business applied and did not receive TARPTR funding; No data available: business did not apply* for TARPTR funding. *The data file includes data for Part 1 and Part 2 of the TARPTR, so in some cases businesses would have applied for Part 1 but did not apply for Part 2 (or vice versa).

resource.name: Nova Scotia Assessment Results by Year and Board - Lecture et écriture en 6e année
resource.description: Provides assessment results for Reading (scaled score and performance level) and Writing (performance level for four components of writing) for each year assessment has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the assessments.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of July 28, 2021. French (CSAP) program Grade 6 students write this assessment on two days in late October. French Immersion students do not write this assessment.  For the reading portion of the assessment, students read different types of texts and answered questions about what they read. For the writing portion of the assessment, students completed two writing tasks. Student performance in writing was reported for the four components: Ideas, Organization, Language Use and Conventions. Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) Level 4 (above the expectation). Students also received a scaled score in reading (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800). Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to build this assessment, score the writing tasks and set the performance expectations in Reading and Writing. The expectation is what students should know and be able to do on their own at the beginning of grade 6. As of April 1, 2018, Nova Scotia Regional School Boards became Regional Centres for Education (RCE). Geographical areas for regional centres and their historical school boards can be found here: https://novascotia.ca/just/regulations/regs/edregcen.htm . The Conseil scolaire acadien provincial (CSAP) remained the same.

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The station location dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/dhns-eqjr) contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique Deployment ID which can be used to filter and separate individual datasets for export from the Open Data Portal. Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs), Xeos wind-wave buoys, and MarineLabs wind-wave buoys consist of time-series measurements of significant wave height, wave period, and average wave direction. Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. Note that some observations of 0m wave height may reflect false zero recordings, and analyses should be conducted accordingly.  Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the ADCPs presents wave height (significant, maximum, height average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in metres, and period (peak, maximum, period average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in seconds. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the wind-wave buoys presents wave height (significant, maximum) in metres and average wave direction in degrees relative to true north, corrected for localized magnetic declination specific to the deployment coordinates.   The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements) can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. Date and time data are in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

resource.name: Family Pharmacare Payment and Utilization by Management Zone
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Family Pharmacare Program is a provincial drug insurance plan designed to help Nova Scotians with the cost of their prescription drugs. The Program offers protection against drug costs for families who have no drug coverage or if the cost of the prescription drugs becomes a financial burden to them. The Program is available to all Nova Scotians with a valid Nova Scotia Health Card.
This dataset lists the summary payment and utilization of the program by health management zone for multiple fiscal years.

domain_metadata.value: - Data originates from tables 8.14 and 8.15 of the annual Medical Services Insurance R-70 Annual Statistical Tables report - Data is based on date of service - Total Cost of Claims represent the total expenditures of the prorgram not only the Department of Health expenditure. - Beneficiaries are persons receiving insured services.

resource.name: Crime Statistics - Incidents and rates by offence category
resource.description: The dataset includes incident-based crime statistics at the provincial and police service level. Statistics include the number of incidents of offences and rates per 100,000 population for total Criminal Code violations (excluding traffic), total violent Criminal Code violations, total property crime violations, and total "other" Criminal Code violations. This data is sourced from Statistics Canada through CANSIM.

domain_metadata.value: CANSIM Table 252-0075 Incident-based crime statistics, by detailed violations and police services, Atlantic provinces (http://www5.statcan.gc.ca/cansim/a26?lang=eng&id=2520075); CANSIM Table 252-0051 Incident-based crime statistics, by detailed violations (http://www5.statcan.gc.ca/cansim/a26?lang=eng&id=2520051)

Current as of September 1, 2023. 1) During the production of each year's crime statistics, data from the previous year are revised to reflect any updates or changes that have been received from the police services. 2) Homicide data are extracted by Statistics Canada from its Homicide Survey database. All other data is based on police reported incidents of crime reported through the Uniform Crime Reporting Survey. 3) For areas with small population counts, rates may be suppressed; signified by "x". 4) Where data is unavailable, the cell has been marked by "..".

resource.name: Atlantic Quarterly Autumn 2017 - DHW (flu shots)

resource.name: Nomination Certificates Issued
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who fulfil a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa.   

The maximum number of certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of February 3, 2023. A nomination certificate may represent one or more people.  Each nomination certificate issued includes the principal applicant and any family members (spouse and dependents) expected to accompany them to Canada.   A nomination by the Province of Nova Scotia does not guarantee that the applicant will become a permanent resident. The federal government has the final decision on who receives permanent residency and is admissible to Canada based on various considerations that include, but are not limited to, health, criminality and security checks.

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) coordinates an extensive Coastal Monitoring Program to measure essential ocean variables (EOVs) throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters. This dataset includes data from the Current branch of the program. Data from the Water Quality and Wave branches of the program are also available on the Nova Scotia Open Data Portal. CMAR has worked with the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) and marine service providers to measure ocean current at various locations in Nova Scotia since 2007. The data is collected with Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) deployed on the seafloor. An ADCP is a hydroacoustic current meter that measures water velocities over a range of depths. These sensors measure soundwaves scattered back from moving particles in the water column and use the Doppler effect to estimate speed and direction.  Current data is organized by county. Each county dataset includes data from multiple ADCP deployments that vary in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when analyzing the data. The “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) summarises the specifications of each deployment. Individual deployments are identified in the county dataset and metadata by a unique ID in the deployment_id column.   The county datasets are large and can exceed the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the waterbody, station, and/or deployment_id of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/688u-j4en).   Current data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) Summary reports for each county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. Data have been trimmed of side-lobe interference. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. CMAR recommends users apply additional quality control prior to using the data. If you have accessed any of the Current data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

domain_metadata.value: Chart (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Guysborough-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Averag/gvmv-b2s3) and Coastal Monitoring Program Report: Guysborough County (https://cmar.ca/reports/)

The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) measures essential ocean variables throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters as part of the Coastal Monitoring Program. This program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in 2012 and CMAR became involved in 2017. CMAR collects water quality data (temperature, dissolved oxygen, and intermittent salinity) using autonomous sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or dragging.  The Coastal Monitoring Program data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the WATERBODY, STATION, DEPTH, VARIABLE, and/or TIMESTAMP of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Guysborough-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Averag/gvmv-b2s3).   Water Quality Data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/reports/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server through the Canadian Integrated Ocean Observing System (CIOOS) platform (https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset?q=cmar). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses.  A note on units: For Halifax and Lunenburg counties, dissolved oxygen was measured in units of percent saturation or mg/L, depending on the sensor. For all other counties, dissolved oxygen was measured in units of percent saturation. Measurements in mg/L were corrected for salinity using the Garcia-Gordon (1992) salinity correction factor with a salinity value of 30.6 practical salinity units (based on available data for the region). This correction factor is not required for values recorded in percent saturation. Please contact info@cmar.ca for more information.  If you have accessed any of the Coastal Monitoring Program data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

resource.name: Healthcare Worker Influenza Immunization Rates
resource.description: Healthcare worker influenza immunization rates represents the influenza immunization rates for healthcare workers within the Nova Scotia Health Authority and the IWK.  The rates are collected and reported annually by the health authorities.  Healthcare workers who get the flu vaccine provide a layer of protection to themselves and to patients from getting influenza and help prevent influenza outbreaks. Measuring, monitoring, and reporting the rate of healthcare worker influenza immunization can assist hospitals with evaluating the effectiveness of their occupational health/infection prevention and control programs and explore ways to increase the number of healthcare workers who get the flu shot. Data fields include: Year, Health Authority, Health Authority Zone, Immunization Rate, Provincial Target

resource.name: Nova Scotia Lake Survey Lakes Locations
resource.description:
A shapefile of freshwater water bodies hat have been sampled as part of the Nova Scotia Lake Survey. The Nova Scotia Lake Survey program is a partnership initiative between Nova Scotia Environment (NSE) and Nova Scotia Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) to inventory lakes throughout the province determining baseline water quality, in support of both sport fisheries and water resource management areas.

The following weblink connects to a Nova Scotia Environment web map that includes the locations of the monitored lakes within the province and an alternative method for downloading the same lake chemistry dataset: http://nse.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=7ded7a30bef44f848e8a4fc8672c89bd

resource.name: Active Driver Licences by Class and Age Group
resource.description: Number of active driver licences by driver licence class and age range. Driver licence classes include: Class 1 = for driving semi-trailers and tractor-trailer combinations; Class 2 = for driving buses with more than 24 passengers; Class 3 = for driving vehicles or vehicle-trailer combinations weighing more than 14,000 kg; Class 4 = for driving buses/vans 24 passengers and under for compensation, taxis, rideshares and ambulances; Class 5 = for driving cars, pick-up trucks, sport utility vehicles and vans with less than 24 passenger capacity; Class 6 = for driving motorcycles and motor-driven cycles; Class 7 = learner's licence for those learning to drive class 5 vehicles; Class 8 = for driving farm tractors. These descriptions could be used somewhere on the page to describe each class of driver licence.

domain_metadata.value: Class 1-5 and 8 Driver licences are renewed every 5 years on an individuals day and month of birth. Class 7 Driver Licences are valid for 2 years from the date of issuance. Blank cells indicate less than 5 active driver licences in a specific driver licence class and age category.
Initial point in time as of June 1, 2021 and then subsequent updates bi-annually in February and August.

resource.description: School-Based Immunization Coverage in Nova Scotia. Includes the following data fields: Year, Zone, Vaccine Type, # Immunized, # Eligible, % Coverage, 95% CI

domain_metadata.value: Current as of Feb 5, 2024. - Tetanus, Diphtheria, and Pertussis (TDAP) is administered in a single dose vaccine. Provincial vaccine coverage target is ≥ 90%.  - 2014-15 was the final year that Meningococcal Group C Conjugate (Men-C-C) single dose vaccine was delivered. Beginning in 2015-16, the Meningococcal Quadrivalent (Men-C-ACYW) single dose vaccine has been administered. Men-C-ACYW protects againsts illnesses caused from serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 of the bacteria whereas the prior vaccine provided protection against serogroup C.  Provincial coverage target for both variantions of this vaccine is ≥ 90%.  - 2014-15 was the final year that Human Papillomavirus (HPV) three dose vaccine was delivered to female students. Beginning in 2015-16, the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) two dose vaccine has been administered to both male and female students. The provincial coverage target for this vaccine is ≥ 80%.  - Hepatitis B (HPB) is administered in a two dose vaccine. Provincial coverage target for this vaccine is ≥ 90%. - 95% CI represents the range of values that you can be 95% certain contains the true mean of the population. - The total for Nova Scotia may not always equal the sum of the four zones as there is immunization data reports occasionally that is not identified to a zone.

resource.name: Invest Nova Scotia Investment TVPI Ratio
resource.description:
Invest Nova Scotia is Nova Scotia’s business development agency that works to promote economic growth and community economic development in the province by enabling business, innovation, sustainability and entrepreneurship. 

Early stage deep technology start-ups are a key focus area for Invest Nova Scotia. They are supported through venture capital, incubation facilities, expert advice, and other acceleration initiatives.

Invest Nova Scotia makes equity investments through the Nova Scotia First Fund (NSFF), a venture capital fund backed by the Nova Scotia government.

NSFF’s overall objective is to generate a return for Nova Scotia. This is measured by the total value of the investment portfolio (i.e., realized distributions and unrealized changes in value) to the total amount contributed by the Nova Scotia government (Modified TVPI ratio*).

This dataset gives Invest Nova Scotia’s annual TVPI ratios.

* Invest Nova Scotia’s TVPI ratios represent only the gross performance of the investments; they do not account for the costs of managing the portfolio, which are included in the organization’s operating budget.
columns_name: TVPI Ratio (total value to paid-in capital)

resource.name: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bloodstream infection rates in patients while in hospital
resource.description: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bloodstream infection rates while in hospital are measured and monitored by infection prevention and control staff as a means to evaluate the effectiveness of their infection control protocols. MRSA rates are calculated by dividing the number of clostridium difficile infections by the total number of patient days. This rate is then multiplied by 10,000 to make a standard MRSA infection rate for each reporting period. The rate is reported per 10,000 patient days. The Canadian benchmark MRSA rate is included in the dataset. Data fields include: Year, Quarter, Health Authority, Health Authority Zone, MRSA Rate, Canadian benchmark.

Benchmark changed to 1.12 from 0.57 as of Q1 2022-23.

domain_metadata.value: French (CSAP) program Grade 3 students write this assessment on two days in late October. French Immersion students do not write this assessment. For the reading portion of the assessment, students read different types of texts and answered questions about what they read. Individual student results were reported in three levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), and Level 3 and above (at or above the expectation). For the writing portion of the assessment, students completed two writing tasks. Student performance in writing was reported for the four components Ideas, Organization, Language Use and Conventions in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) Level 4 (above the expectation). Students also received a scaled score in reading (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800). Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to build this assessment, score the writing tasks and set the performance expectations in Reading and Writing. The expectation is what students should know and be able to do on their own at the beginning of grade 3. As of April 1, 2018, Nova Scotia Regional School Boards became Regional Centres for Education (RCE). unique identifier for ADCP deployment. IDs are assigned incrementally by deployment date within a county. A skipped ID (e.g., consecutive IDs are XY001 and XY003) indicates that an ADCP was deployed but no useable current data were recovered (e.g., the battery failed).

direction of water flow for corresponding depth bin and timestamp (degrees). Measured travelling away from the ADCP sensor relative to True North (a reading of 90 degrees describes current travelling from west to east).
waterbody in which the ADCP was deployed.

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) coordinates an extensive Coastal Monitoring Program to measure essential ocean variables (EOVs) throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters. This dataset includes data from the Current branch of the program. Data from the Water Quality and Wave branches of the program are also available on the Nova Scotia Open Data Portal. CMAR has worked with the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) and marine service providers to measure ocean current at various locations in Nova Scotia since 2007. The data is collected with Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) deployed on the seafloor. An ADCP is a hydroacoustic current meter that measures water velocities over a range of depths. These sensors measure soundwaves scattered back from moving particles in the water column and use the Doppler effect to estimate speed and direction.  Current data is organized by county. Each county dataset includes data from multiple ADCP deployments that vary in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when analyzing the data. The “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) summarises the specifications of each deployment. Individual deployments are identified in the county dataset and metadata by a unique ID in the deployment_id column.   The county datasets are large and can exceed the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the waterbody, station, and/or deployment_id of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/btag-qamr).   Current data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha). Summary reports for each county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. Data have been trimmed of side-lobe interference. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. CMAR recommends users apply additional quality control prior to using the data. If you have accessed any of the Current data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

domain_metadata.value: Chart (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Colchester-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average/cx5r-jnfx) and Coastal Monitoring Program Report: Colchester County (https://cmar.ca/reports/)

The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) measures essential ocean variables throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters as part of the Coastal Monitoring Program. This program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in 2012 and CMAR became involved in 2017. CMAR collects water quality data (temperature, dissolved oxygen, and intermittent salinity) using autonomous sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or dragging.  The Coastal Monitoring Program data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the WATERBODY, STATION, DEPTH, VARIABLE, and/or TIMESTAMP of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Colchester-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average/cx5r-jnfx). Water Quality Data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/reports/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server through the Canadian Integrated Ocean Observing System (CIOOS) platform (https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset?q=cmar). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses.  A note on units: For Halifax and Lunenburg counties, dissolved oxygen was measured in units of percent saturation or mg/L, depending on the sensor. For all other counties, dissolved oxygen was measured in units of percent saturation. Measurements in mg/L were corrected for salinity using the Garcia-Gordon (1992) salinity correction factor with a salinity value of 30.6 practical salinity units (based on available data for the region). This correction factor is not required for values recorded in percent saturation. Please contact info@cmar.ca for more information.  If you have accessed any of the Coastal Monitoring Program data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The station location dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/dhns-eqjr) contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique Deployment ID which can be used to filter and separate individual datasets for export from the Open Data Portal. Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs), Xeos wind-wave buoys, and MarineLabs wind-wave buoys consist of time-series measurements of significant wave height, wave period, and average wave direction. Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. Note that some observations of 0m wave height may reflect false zero recordings, and analyses should be conducted accordingly. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the ADCPs presents wave height (significant, maximum, height average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in metres, and period (peak, maximum, period average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in seconds. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the wind-wave buoys presents wave height (significant, maximum) in metres and average wave direction in degrees relative to true north, corrected for localized magnetic declination specific to the deployment coordinates. The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements) can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. Date and time data are in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

resource.name: Labour Market Classification of Nominees
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

LSI uses the National Occupational Classification (NOC) 2016 to designate which occupational group nominees fall under. The NOC is the nationally accepted reference on occupations in Canada. It organizes over 40,000 job titles into 500 occupational group descriptions. Detailed information on the NOC can be found at http://noc.esdc.gc.ca/English/home.aspx.

This dataset provides the number of certificates issued annually by NOC Skill Level, NOC Code (4 digits), and Occupational Group: 
* Skill Level corresponds to the type and/or amount of training or education typically required to work in an occupation;
* The 4-digit NOC code is comprised of 500 occupational groups identified as unit groups; 
* Occupational Groups describe each of the 500 unit groups in plain language terms such as Financial auditors and accountants;  Mining engineers; and Audiologists and speech-language pathologists.

The maximum number of certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of February 3, 2023. A nomination by the Province of Nova Scotia does not guarantee that the applicant will become a permanent resident. The federal government has the final decision on who receives permanent residency and is admissible to Canada based on various considerations that include, but are not limited to, health, criminality and security checks.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Government Pay Scales
resource.description: Nova Scotia Government Pay scales based upon effective period start and end dates. Start Date, End Date, Pay Plan Type, Pay Plan, Pay Plan Level, Biweekly Pay Rate, Hourly Pay Rate

domain_metadata.value: Data Dictionary of Nova Scotia Government Pay Scales Open Data Dataset - EN.pdf

Current as of May 2023. Pay scales for the entire Nova Scotia Provincial Government (NSPG), excluding: JUDGES (Judges), MLA (Legislative Services MLAs), AC (Old Correctional Workers - on WCB),  BIWEEKLY (Biweekly Paid), AS (Old Admin Services Excluded - on LTD), GRADE (Nova Scotia Business Inc. NSBI), HOURLY (Hourly Paid), MCP (Old Management Classification Plan Excluded - on LTD), NSBI (Nova Scotia Business Inc. NSBI), EDC (Old Agricultural College - on LTD).  *Notes to consider when using this dataset: a) Start and end dates will specify the effective period of time the pay scale is active, as entered into the Province of Nova Scotia's SAP transactional system. Effective period dates can vary according to collective agreements currently in effect. Most classification effective dates run from April 1 - March 31, however CUPE effective dates run from November 1 - October 31. As contracts are negotiated, pay scales can change, even retroactively. This dataset is re-loaded annually, and may not contain new or retroactive changes resulting from negotiations until the next annual refresh. Refer to published Collective Agreements in these cases.  b) Pay Plan Type is either Excluded (Non-Union) or Bargaining Unit (Union) c) If Pay Plan Level is blank, there are no Pay Plan Levels for the specified Pay Plan d) For a specified Pay Plan and/or Level, there will only be a Bi-weekly or Hourly Pay Rate, not both (one will be blank) e) If you try to expand Hourly Pay Rates to Bi-weekly Amounts or Hourly/Bi-weekly Pay Rates to Annual Amounts, they will be estimates only (factors such as varying work hours and the number of annual pay periods will vary from year to year).  This dataset has a supplemental document which contains information on its data structure element and attribute definitions: Data Dictionary of Nova Scotia Government Pay Scales Open Data Dataset - EN.pdf

The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements) can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. Date and time data are in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

resource.name: Nova Scotia Assessment Results by Year and Board - Lecture et écriture en 8e année
resource.description: Provides assessment results for Reading (scaled score and performance level) and Writing (performance level for four components of writing) for each year assessment has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the assessments.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of July 28, 2021. Assessments were not administered for 2016-2017 school year. French (CSAP) program Grade 8 students write this assessment in June. French Immersion students do not write this assessment.  For the reading portion of the assessment, students read different types of texts and answered questions about what they read. For the writing portion of the assessment, students completed two writing tasks. Student performance in writing was reported for the four components: Ideas, Organization, Language Use and Conventions. Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) Level 4 (above the expectation). Students also received a scaled score in reading (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800). Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to build this assessment, score the writing tasks and set the performance expectations in Reading and Writing. The expectation is what students should know and be able to do on their own at the end of grade 8. As of April 1, 2018, Nova Scotia Regional School Boards became Regional Centres for Education (RCE). Geographical areas for regional centres and their historical school boards can be found here: https://novascotia.ca/just/regulations/regs/edregcen.htm . The Conseil scolaire acadien provincial (CSAP) remained the same.

resource.name: Family Pharmacare Program – Payment and Utilization
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Family Pharmacare Program is a provincial drug insurance plan designed to help Nova Scotians with the cost of their prescription drugs. The Program offers protection against drug costs for families who have no drug coverage or if the cost of the prescription drugs becomes a financial burden to them. The Program is available to all Nova Scotians with a valid Nova Scotia Health Card.
This dataset lists the summarized payment and utilization of the program for multiple fiscal years.

resource.name: Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network Station Locations
resource.description:
A shapefile of the Nova Scotia Automated Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network monitoring stations. The network was established in 2002 to assess near real-time water quality in surface waters across the province at five river stations and one lake station. The results are used to help manage water resources, determine baseline water quality in lakes and watercourses throughout the province, evaluate the impact of human activities on surface water, and assess long term trends in water quality. 

The following weblink connects to a Nova Scotia Department of Environment and Climate Change web map that includes the six monitoring station locations and an alternative method for downloading the same dataset: http://nse.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=7ded7a30bef44f848e8a4fc8672c89bd

domain_metadata.value: The digital product includes points for each of the six monitoring station locations. The Pockwock Lake, Shelburne River, North East Margaree River, Kelley River and LaHave River stations are co-located with real-time water quality monitoring stations. Quarterly water quality samples are collected and submitted for laboratory analysis at all six stations.  Disclaimer The Province of Nova Scotia makes no representations, express or implied, as to the accuracy, completeness and timeliness of the information, maps and other data provided through this application.  The mapping is a graphical representation not based on survey and cannot be used for any legal or navigational purpose.  Any conclusions drawn or decisions made, based on an interpretation of the data, are the sole responsibility of the user.  By continuing to use the application, the user agrees to the terms of this disclaimer.

domain_metadata.value: Under the Poultry Insurance Plan: “breeder” means a hen that is owned by a Nova Scotia farmer and grown in the Province for the purpose of producing broiler or layer chicks;   “pullet” means a female chicken that is younger than 19 weeks of age and that has been produced for the purpose of laying eggs for human consumption.  “broiler” means a chicken that is owned by a Nova Scotia farmer and grown in the Province for the purpose of producing meat under a licence issued by the Chicken Farmers of Nova Scotia in accordance with the Chicken Farmers of Nova Scotia Regulations made under the Natural Products Act;  “breeder pullet” means a pullet that is owned by a Nova Scotia farmer and grown in the Province for the purpose of producing replacement breeder stock;  “commercial layer” means a hen that is purchased from a pullet grower, owned by a Nova Scotia farmer and grown in the Province for the purpose of producing eggs under a licence issued by the Nova Scotia Egg Producers in accordance with the Nova Scotia Egg Producers’ Marketing Plan made under the Natural Products Act;  The Nova Scotia Crop and Livestock Insurance Commission fosters private sector economic growth through its voluntary crop and livestock based AgriInsurance programs that adds a degree of predictability to farm businesses by protecting against the effects of yield reductions and crop or livestock losses caused by naturally occurring perils. resource.name: Digby County Current Data
resource.description: Current speed and direction time series data collected in a vertical profile at various locations throughout the coastal waters of Digby County.
columns_description: specific area where ADCP was deployed.
the depth of the ADCP below the surface (metres), measured by the ADCP sensor. Changes with the tide.

distance from the surface to the centre of the measurement bin (metres). Calculated as sensor_depth_below_surface_m + sensor_height_above_sea_floor_m - bin_height_above_sea_floor_m. See “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) for sensor_height_above_sea_floor_m.
distance from the seafloor to the centre of the measurement bin (metres).
water speed for corresponding depth bin and timestamp (m / s).

direction of water flow for corresponding depth bin and timestamp (degrees). Measured travelling away from the ADCP sensor relative to True North (a reading of 90 degrees describes current travelling from west to east).
waterbody in which the ADCP was deployed.

unique identifier for ADCP deployment. IDs are assigned incrementally by deployment date within a county. A skipped ID (e.g., consecutive IDs are XY001 and XY003) indicates that an ADCP was deployed but no useable current data were recovered (e.g., the battery failed).

timestamp of the start of the ensemble (in UTC). Current speed and direction recorded at each timestamp are an average of many measurements recoded during the ensemble. See the “Nova Scotia Current Data Deployment Information” dataset for ensemble details for each deployment.

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) coordinates an extensive Coastal Monitoring Program to measure essential ocean variables (EOVs) throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters. This dataset includes data from the Current branch of the program. Data from the Water Quality and Wave branches of the program are also available on the Nova Scotia Open Data Portal. CMAR has worked with the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) and marine service providers to measure ocean current at various locations in Nova Scotia since 2007. The data is collected with Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) deployed on the seafloor. An ADCP is a hydroacoustic current meter that measures water velocities over a range of depths. These sensors measure soundwaves scattered back from moving particles in the water column and use the Doppler effect to estimate speed and direction.  Current data is organized by county. Each county dataset includes data from multiple ADCP deployments that vary in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when analyzing the data. The “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) summarises the specifications of each deployment. Individual deployments are identified in the county dataset and metadata by a unique ID in the deployment_id column.   The county datasets are large and can exceed the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the waterbody, station, and/or deployment_id of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/n5cx-nesf).   Current data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha). Summary reports for each county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. Data have been trimmed of side-lobe interference. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. CMAR recommends users apply additional quality control prior to using the data. If you have accessed any of the Current data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

resource.name: Numbers and rates of substance-related fatalities in Nova Scotia
resource.description: This dataset contains frequencies, rates, and proportions that describe drug toxicity deaths in Nova Scotia over time and space and by certain demographic and contextual characteristics. See usage considerations for further details on these data.
columns_name: Rate per 100,000 population (annualized for quarterly data)
columns_description: Living situation of decedent at time of death

Manner of death refers to the mode of method of death and is classified as one of five manners: natural; accident; suicide; homicide; undetermined (https://nslegislature.ca/sites/default/files/legc/statutes/fatality%20investigations.pdf). Acute toxicity deaths are not classified as natural in manner and therefore this dataset excludes deaths for which manner was classified as natural. Data are presented for manners suicide and accident.
Percent of cases in that year with that characteristic
Number of deaths reported and investigated by NSMES, confirmed and probable toxicity deaths
Year and month of death or when individual was found dead
Quarter in which individual died or was found dead. Q1 = Jan-Mar; Q2 = Apr-Jun; Q3 = Jul-Sep; Q4 Oct-Dec.
Describes whether contextual information available suggests others were present or aware that decedent was using substances prior to death
Type of substance contributing to toxicity death
Month of death or month individual was found dead
Year of death or year individual was found dead
Place of toxicity event
Number of cases per 100,000 population using Statistics Canada census population estimates; Crude rate per 100,000 population
Describes whether the drugs that contributed to the toxicity death as certified in the cause of death statement belonged to drug class opioids or stimulants (or both or neither)
Sex
Health zone of residence

domain_metadata.value: NSMES acute toxicity deaths classification.pdf, NSMES data definitions.pdf

Data are current as of March 2, 2024 (when data for 2022 onward were updated as necessary). Data are extracted from a live database environment and are provisional and subject to change. Some case investigations in recent years remain ongoing. Data here include both confirmed and probable toxicity deaths. Probable drug toxicity deaths will either become confirmed cases once cause of death is certified, or will be determined to not be a toxicity death (death from another cause) and removed from these counts in future data releases. 'All manners' category includes deaths where manner was classified as either accident, suicide, or undetermined. (Acute toxicity deaths are not classified as natural in manner of death, and no toxicity deaths were classified as homicide.) Data reflect cause and manner of death recorded on death certificate. Geocoding of address data has resulted in reclassification of zone of residence for a small number of cases (compared to prior releases of data). Population data have been updated with the most recent available data from Statistics Canada (17-10-0134-01; rate data may differ slightly from previous releases).  Data includes deaths caused by acute toxicity following administration of exogenous substance(s), including pharmaceutical and nonpharmaceutical drugs and alcohol. Excludes: gases and inhalants, death due to medical consequences of long term substance use, medical assistance in dying, trauma with substances detected but not involved in the mechanism of death. NS totals may be greater than sum of health zones as totals include cases where location of residence was out of province. Totals will also be greater than the sum of accident and suicide where cases remain under investigation and/or manner was certified as 'undetermined'. Data for substances are not mutually exclusive as some deaths are due to toxicity from multiple substances, which may act synergistically to cause death (and may or may not have reached lethal levels alone). As such, counts of deaths by substance cannot be added together for meaningful sums. See the ‘All substances’ category for overall counts of unique deaths and associated rates.    This dataset includes categories for drug type. Drug-specific data rely on toxicology findings which have a typical lag of 2-8 weeks. Fields are empty when column is not applicable to that data indicator.  See related document 'NSMES acute toxicity deaths classification' for electronic application key word search terms applied to immediate cause of death and all antecedent causes of death for each drug type category.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Mineral Resources Development Fund (MRDF) Grant Recipients
resource.description: The MRDF is designed to assist prospectors, exploration companies, and researchers, employ post-secondary students, and support projects in the mining sector that attract investment and grow Nova Scotia's economy and create jobs, especially in rural areas. The data published includes the file number, the Grant recipient, the applicant, the Company, the Project Name, the Commodity and the Amount awarded.

domain_metadata.value: MRDF is the acronym for Mineral Resources Development Fund. Education, Outreach, and Engagement Grants provide up to $50K. Innovation Grants provide currently up to $100K, from 2018-2020 they provided up to $200K. Major Projects Grants offer up to $500K (or higher if required).  Marketing Grants don't currently have a $ amount threshold (as they are typically used for conferences). Post Secondary Research Grants offer up to $90K. Prospecting and Exploration Grants offered in 2021-22, up to a maximum of $30K (plus $5K for student funding available); In 2020-21, they offered up to a maximum of $30K (plus $5K for student funding available); In 2019-20, they offered up to a maximum of $20K (plus $5K for student funding available); In 2018-19, they offered up to a maximum of $20K. Research Grants offer a maximum of $90K. Shared Funding Exploration Grants offer in 2021-22,  >$30K up to $100K (50/50); In 2020-21, >$30K up to $200K (50/50); In 2019-20,  >$20K up to $200K (50/50) and in 2018-19, >$20K up to $200K (50/50). Tier II Marketing Grant, only for 2019-20, offered a maximum of $90K.

resource.name: Bills introduced in the Nova Scotia Legislature
resource.description: List of bills introduced in the Nova Scotia Legislature from 1995 to the present.  Data set includes links to Status of Bills page and the bill as introduced.  If the bill was passed by the legislature, there is also a link to the bill as assented to by the Lieutenant Governor.
columns_description: The date that the bill last changed its status.
The current status of the bill.
Short title of a bill, which is a proposed law to create an entirely new law or to change an existing one. To become law, a bill must pass three readings, committee study and be given Royal Assent.
The consecutive number the clerk assigns to a bill based upon when it is introduced in the House.
After an election, the members form a new general assembly, which is numbered consecutively.  A session is a series of sittings of the House of Assembly during a General Assembly.
The final stage in the consideration of a bill. Members have a chance to comment on, criticize, or ask questions about the bill again before voting on it for the last time.
The first stage in the passage of a bill into law. The sponsoring member briefly introduces the bill. First reading always passes without debate or vote.

French Immersion students write a French translation of this assessment. Students answered questions in each of the mathematics strands (number and operations, patterns and relations, measurement and geometry, and statistics and probability). Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) and Level 4 (above the expectation).Students also received a scaled score in mathematics (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800).  Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to develop this assessment and to set the performance expectation, which is what students should know and be able to do on their own at the beginning of grade 4. resource.name: Industry Specialization based on Employment by Functional Economic Regions
resource.description: The dataset provides information on industry specialization, industry structure and employment for Nova Scotia’s Functional Economic Regions.  The data fields include: Functional Economic Region Name, North American Industry Classification (NAICS) - 4-digits; Category and Type of Industry; Location Quotient by Employment; and Level of Specialization category.  Fields may be updated or change over time.
columns_description: Location Quotient based on Employment
North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) - 4 digits
Level of Specialization
Functional Economic Region Name

domain_metadata.value: PDFs of Regional Profiles of Nova Scotia's Functional Regions can be found at https://data.novascotia.ca/Business-and-Industry/Industry-Specialization-based-on-Business-Location/cyje-iisx

Industry specialization can be measured using Location Quotients (LQ) that compare the regional share of employment in an industry with the national share of employment in the same industry.  An LQ greater than 1 suggests the number of employment in an industry is more concentrated in the region than it is nationally.  An LQ greater than 2 indicates a very high level of specialization or concentration, 1.25 to 2 indicates a high specialization; an LQ close to 1 (0.75-1.25) indicates an average specialization; and less than 0.75 indicates a low specialization.  An LQ of 0 for a particular industry means that no employment in that particular industry exists in the region according to the Census.
Employment is based on those who reported employment income in 2015.

resource.name: [ARCHIVED] Nova Scotia Groundwater Observation Well Temperature Data
resource.description: [ARCHIVED] Recommendation is to discontinue the “Nova Scotia Groundwater Observation Well Temperature Data”. This is for scientific / technical reasons. The data was never designed to be collected as a dataset on its own, but is used by sensors to create a correction facter for other data (groundwater levels). Developments in academic research show that the type of water wells we monitor for groundwater levels do not have the correct design for measuring temperature, with issues that include the potential within wells for thermal convection cells that cause groundwater temperature readings to fluctuate inconsistently. Groundwater temperatures have been recorded from the NS Groundwater Observation Well monitoring network since 2003. This temperature data is presented as daily averages and may be influenced by a number of variable factors including air temperature, well construction, depth, geology and groundwater conditions.
