resource.name: [Archived] Trade Mission or International Engagement
resource.description: [ARCHIVED] The Province of Nova Scotia recognizes the importance of foreign engagement and regularly engages in government to government and government to business relations globally. In order to ensure that effective and positive international government relations are developed and maintained, the Nova Scotia Department of Intergovernmental Affairs has been mandated to foster and promote intergovernmental /international relations globally. Developing and enhancing meaningful intergovernmental/international relationships is an incremental process. Intergovernmental/international relations can be achieved through a number of primary activities: out-bound trade and business missions; incoming trade and business missions; and Nova Scotia government to foreign government/foreign business promotion. Mission reports are a key accounting of government activity and reflect the various specific events and key follow up activities.

resource.name: Clostridium difficile Infection (CDI) rates in patients while in hospital
resource.description: Clostridium difficile Infection (CDI) rates while in hospital are measured and monitored by infection prevention and control staff as a means to evaluate the effectiveness of their infection control protocols. CDI rates are calculated by dividing the number of clostridium difficile infections by the total number of patient days. This rate is then multiplied by 10,000 to make a standard CDI infection rate for each reporting period. The rate is reported per 10,000 patient days. The Canadian benchmark CDI rate is included in the dataset. Data fields include: Year, Quarter, Health Authority, Health Authority Zone, CDI Rate, Canadian benchmark

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) coordinates an extensive Coastal Monitoring Program to measure essential ocean variables (EOVs) throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters. This dataset includes data from the Current branch of the program. Data from the Water Quality and Wave branches of the program are also available on the Nova Scotia Open Data Portal. CMAR has worked with the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) and marine service providers to measure ocean current at various locations in Nova Scotia since 2007. The data is collected with Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) deployed on the seafloor. An ADCP is a hydroacoustic current meter that measures water velocities over a range of depths. These sensors measure soundwaves scattered back from moving particles in the water column and use the Doppler effect to estimate speed and direction.  Current data is organized by county. Each county dataset includes data from multiple ADCP deployments that vary in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when analyzing the data. The “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) summarises the specifications of each deployment. Individual deployments are identified in the county dataset and metadata by a unique ID in the deployment_id column.   The county datasets are large and can exceed the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the waterbody, station, and/or deployment_id of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/b4qv-zmqj).   Current data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha). Summary reports for each county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. Data have been trimmed of side-lobe interference. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. CMAR recommends users apply additional quality control prior to using the data. domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research’s (CMAR) Coastal Monitoring Program provides high resolution data on ocean variables from around the coast of Nova Scotia. The program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in the early 1990s. In 2019, CMAR assumed responsibility for the program and expanded its scope and mandate. Through the Water Quality Branch of the program, CMAR collects temperature, dissolved oxygen, and salinity data using sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or grappling methods. Automated Quality Control tests have been applied to the data to identify outlying and unexpected observations. The results of these tests are summarized in the “qc_flag” columns of the dataset. Each data point is assigned a flag value of “Pass”, “Suspect/Of Interest”, “Fail”, or “Not Evaluated”. Observations flagged as “Pass” passed all tests and can be included in analyses. Dissolved oxygen observations flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” likely indicate biofouling signals and should be excluded from analysis or used with extreme caution. Observations for other variables flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” should be reviewed before being included in analyses. Observations flagged as “Fail” should be excluded from most analyses. Some tests cannot be applied to certain observations, which will be flagged as “Not Evaluated”. These observations can typically be included in analyses. Flags should be used as a guide only, and data users are responsible for evaluating the quality of the data prior to use in any analysis. For more information about the Quality Control tests, visit the CMAR Data Governance website (https://dempsey-cmar.github.io/cmp-data-governance/pages/cmp_about.html). The Coastal Monitoring Program Water Quality data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends filtering the data to the waterbody, station, depth, quality control flag, and/or time period of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/d6fb-k8yz). The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on this Portal shows additional locations with available Water Quality data collected through CMAR’s Coastal Monitoring Program (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server through the Canadian Integrated Ocean Observing System (CIOOS) platform (https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset?q=cmar). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. If you have accessed any Coastal Monitoring Program data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform. Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data. Contact info@cmar.ca for more information.

resource.name: Nominee Certificates Issued by Stream
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Certificates are issued in particular streams of the Nominee Program, and each stream has different eligibility criteria. Over time, streams may close as new streams are developed. This dataset provides the number of certificates issued annually by the streams under which the nomination was made.

See https://novascotiaimmigration.com/move-here/ for information on current streams.

The maximum number of nomination certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of March 9, 2023. A nomination certificate may represent one or more people. Each nomination certificate issued includes the principal applicant and any family members (spouse and dependents) expected to accompany them to Canada.

resource.name: Annapolis County Current Data
resource.description: Current speed and direction time series data collected in a vertical profile at various locations throughout the coastal waters of Annapolis County.
columns_description: direction of water flow for corresponding depth bin and timestamp (degrees). Measured travelling away from the ADCP sensor relative to True North (a reading of 90 degrees describes current travelling from west to east).
water speed for corresponding depth bin and timestamp (m / s).
distance from the seafloor to the centre of the measurement bin (metres).

distance from the surface to the centre of the measurement bin (metres). Calculated as sensor_depth_below_surface_m + sensor_height_above_sea_floor_m - bin_height_above_sea_floor_m. See “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) for sensor_height_above_sea_floor_m.
the depth of the ADCP below the surface (metres), measured by the ADCP sensor. Changes with the tide.

timestamp of the start of the ensemble (in UTC). Current speed and direction recorded at each timestamp are an average of many measurements recoded during the ensemble. See the “Nova Scotia Current Data Deployment Information” dataset for ensemble details for each deployment.
specific area where ADCP was deployed.
waterbody in which the ADCP was deployed.

unique identifier for ADCP deployment. IDs are assigned incrementally by deployment date within a county. A skipped ID (e.g., consecutive IDs are XY001 and XY003) indicates that an ADCP was deployed but no useable current data were recovered (e.g., the battery failed).

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) coordinates an extensive Coastal Monitoring Program to measure essential ocean variables (EOVs) throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters. This dataset includes data from the Current branch of the program. Data from the Water Quality and Wave branches of the program are also available on the Nova Scotia Open Data Portal. CMAR has worked with the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) and marine service providers to measure ocean current at various locations in Nova Scotia since 2007. The data is collected with Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) deployed on the seafloor. An ADCP is a hydroacoustic current meter that measures water velocities over a range of depths. These sensors measure soundwaves scattered back from moving particles in the water column and use the Doppler effect to estimate speed and direction.  Current data is organized by county. Each county dataset includes data from multiple ADCP deployments that vary in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when analyzing the data. The “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) summarises the specifications of each deployment. Individual deployments are identified in the county dataset and metadata by a unique ID in the deployment_id column.   The county datasets are large and can exceed the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the waterbody, station, and/or deployment_id of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/mz4v-dpyc).   Current data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) Summary reports for each county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. Data have been trimmed of side-lobe interference. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. CMAR recommends users apply additional quality control prior to using the data. If you have accessed any of the Current data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

resource.name: Municipal Land Use Planning Comprehensiveness
resource.description:
This dataset provides information about the extent of municipal land use planning in Nova Scotia. Each municipality is listed along with the type of its land use planning described as either comprehensive for entire municipality, comprehensive for local areas only, comprehensive for towns, or single issue.  It also lists the date of the municipal land use plans described. 

A comprehensive strategy is one that address all major areas of concern, for example: residential, commercial, industrial, recreational, environmental, social and economic. A single-issue plan only deals with specific land-use issues such as wind turbines, drinking water protection, general development. Municipal planning strategies may be developed for an entire municipality and/or a local area within its jurisdiction.

domain_metadata.value: Data is a result of a scan done by Provincial planning employees but has not been vetted by the Municipalities

resource.name: Emergency Services Provider Fund
resource.description:
The Emergency Services Provider Fund is a program intended to assist emergency first responder organizations in Nova Scotia with the purchase of equipment used directly in response to a fire or emergency situation. The program will provide up to 75 per cent of the total capital cost up to a maximum grant of $20,000. This dataset includes the list of the providers that were approved, the inital project approval amount and the actual amount paid to each applicant based on the finished project.
Funding for this program was last approved in 2018-19 budget.

domain_metadata.value: The actual amounts paid may differ from the approved amount based on the final project totals. If the finished project total is less than the approved project totals , the actual amount paid may be lower. In the instance where the actual amount is zero, the applicant decided not to proceed with their project  and did not receive any funding.

resource.name: Age of Nominees at Time of Application
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa.

Nominees must generally be between the ages of 21 to 55 at time of application, but the LSI reserves the right to waive this criteria in exceptional circumstances. This dataset provides the number of certificates issued annually by age range. 

The maximum number of certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of February 3, 2023. A nomination by the Province of Nova Scotia does not guarantee that the applicant will become a permanent resident. The federal government has the final decision on who receives permanent residency and is admissible to Canada based on various considerations that include, but are not limited to, health, criminality and security checks.

resource.name: Invest Nova Scotia Start-Up Acceleration Initiative Awards
resource.description:
Invest Nova Scotia is Nova Scotia’s business development agency that works to promote economic growth and community economic development in the province by enabling business, innovation, sustainability and entrepreneurship. 

Early stage deep technology start-ups are a key focus area for Invest Nova Scotia. They are supported through venture capital, incubation facilities, expert advice, and other acceleration initiatives.

This dataset gives information on Invest Nova Scotia’s major acceleration program awards for Nova Scotia start-ups.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of July 9, 2023. Invest Nova Scotia's programs change each year as the needs of Nova Scotia's start-up community evolve.   Some of Invest Nova Scotia’s program awards are co-funded by other organizations, such as the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency.  Fiscal year ends in March.

resource.name: Action for Health
resource.description: The dataset includes various health service-related metrics and indicators related to the Nova Scotia Health. The data is collected from multiple sources within the health system, including Hospital Inpatient, Emergency, Surgical Databases, Continuing Care Home Support and Long-term Care Reports and Emergency Health Services (EHS).The data is aggregated and anonymized to ensure privacy and does not contain any personally identifiable health information. This data set is used to build the Action for Health Public Reporting and the goal of this project is to provide accessible healthcare information to the general public, researchers, and analysts in order to improve understanding and foster improvements in the healthcare system in Nova Scotia.

resource.name: Municipal Financial Capacity and Town Foundation Grants
resource.description:
Municipal Financial Capacity Grant is a legislated unconditional operating grant to assist municipalities whose costs of delivering a core set of services exceed their ability to pay, when compared to similar municipalities. In addition, towns are provided with a $50,000 Town Foundation Grant as recognition of the particular challenges they face due to local road responsibilities and assessment bases. Prior to 2019, the Municipal Financial Capacity Grant was called 'Equalization Grant'. 
The Municipial Grants Act (S.8, s.19A) provides for the payment of the Municipal Financial Capacity Grant and the Town Foundation Grant, which are in the form of unconditional transfers.

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) coordinates an extensive Coastal Monitoring Program to measure essential ocean variables (EOVs) throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters. This dataset includes data from the Current branch of the program. Data from the Water Quality and Wave branches of the program are also available on the Nova Scotia Open Data Portal. CMAR has worked with the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) and marine service providers to measure ocean current at various locations in Nova Scotia since 2007. The data is collected with Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) deployed on the seafloor. An ADCP is a hydroacoustic current meter that measures water velocities over a range of depths. These sensors measure soundwaves scattered back from moving particles in the water column and use the Doppler effect to estimate speed and direction. Current data is organized by county. Each county dataset includes data from multiple ADCP deployments that vary in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when analyzing the data. The “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) summarises the specifications of each deployment. Individual deployments are identified in the county dataset and metadata by a unique ID in the deployment_id column. The county datasets are large and can exceed the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the waterbody, station, and/or deployment_id of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Fishing-and-Aquaculture/Antigonish-County-Daily-Average-Current-Speed-by-D/dxk4-auk4). Current data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) Summary reports for each county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. Data have been trimmed of side-lobe interference. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. CMAR recommends users apply additional quality control prior to using the data. If you have accessed any of the Current data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

domain_metadata.value: *Please note that this data is now outdated, as climate modeling methods have improved since CMIP3. Users seeking updated sea level rise projections for Nova Scotia can find this data at: https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/NS-Sea-Level-Rise-Projections-CMIP5-/t5sw-u3sr Future projections are based on the following time periods: 2025, 2055, 2085, and 2100. This information was generated by the Meteorological Service of Canada at Environment Canada and uses a statistical downscaling method based on the Canadian Global Climate Model (CGCM1).The HHWLT values and the associated sea-level rise and storm-surge component scenarios provided here are linked to specific Canadian Hydrographic Service tide prediction sites and are true only at those locations. The resulting Extreme Total Sea Levels can however be applied to appropriate sections of coastlines once the Chart Datum (CD) to geodetic (CGVD28) conversions have been applied to the point source data. The provision of these conversions was beyond the scope of this project and users will need to obtain these conversions from official sources, such as the Canadian Hydrographic Service.

domain_metadata.value: Chart (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Shelburne-County-Daily-/5ech-4c5t) and Coastal Monitoring Program Report: Shelburne County (https://cmar.ca/reports/)

The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) measures essential ocean variables throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters as part of the Coastal Monitoring Program. This program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in 2012 and CMAR became involved in 2017. CMAR collects water quality data (temperature, dissolved oxygen, and intermittent salinity) using autonomous sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or dragging.  The Coastal Monitoring Program data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the WATERBODY, STATION, DEPTH, VARIABLE, and/or TIMESTAMP of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Shelburne-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average-/5ech-4c5t). Water Quality Data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/reports/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server through the Canadian Integrated Ocean Observing System (CIOOS) platform (https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset?q=cmar). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses.  A note on units: For Halifax and Lunenburg counties, dissolved oxygen was measured in units of percent saturation or mg/L, depending on the sensor. For all other counties, dissolved oxygen was measured in units of percent saturation. Measurements in mg/L were corrected for salinity using the Garcia-Gordon (1992) salinity correction factor with a salinity value of 30.6 practical salinity units (based on available data for the region). This correction factor is not required for values recorded in percent saturation. Please contact info@cmar.ca for more information.  If you have accessed any of the Coastal Monitoring Program data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

Current as of November 2, 2023. 1) During the production of each year's crime statistics, data from the previous year are revised to reflect any updates or changes that have been received from the police services. 2) Homicide data are extracted by Statistics Canada from its Homicide Survey database. All other data is based on police reported incidents of crime reported through the Uniform Crime Reporting Survey. 3) The Uniform Crime Reporting Survey counts any adult and youth charged for the year in which the charge was laid. The homicide totals, which come from The Homicide Survey, count any adult or youth charged with a homicide that occurred in the reference year, regardless of when the charge was laid.

domain_metadata.value: This data shows the type and frequency of consumer complaints submitted online or by paper application to Service Nova Scotia (SNS). We respond to all complaint submissions and submission of a complaint does not necessarily confirm non-compliance on the part of a business. We educate and assist consumers with complaints about the industries we regulate and license, and are pleased to provide education and other sources of help if the complaint falls outside SNS Consumer Protection legislation. Program responsibility for a number of the listed categories falls outside SNS. Although we collect this information, complaints may be registered through other departments, agencies, and organizations which would not be captured in this data. . SNS continues to seek to modernize the way complaints are registered to improve data collection and classification.

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The station location dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/dhns-eqjr) contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique Deployment ID which can be used to filter and separate individual datasets for export from the Open Data Portal. Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs), Xeos wind-wave buoys, and MarineLabs wind-wave buoys consist of time-series measurements of significant wave height, wave period, and average wave direction. Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. Note that some observations of 0m wave height may reflect false zero recordings, and analyses should be conducted accordingly. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the ADCPs presents wave height (significant, maximum, height average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in metres, and period (peak, maximum, period average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in seconds. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the wind-wave buoys presents wave height (significant, maximum) in metres and average wave direction in degrees relative to true north, corrected for localized magnetic declination specific to the deployment coordinates. The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements) can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. Date and time data are in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

domain_metadata.value: Data are current as of March 2, 2024 (when data for 2023 onward were updated as necessary). Data are extracted from a live database environment and are provisional and subject to change. Some case investigations in recent years remain ongoing. NS totals may be greater than sum of zones, as totals include cases from out of province and a small proportion where location of residence is under investigation.  Data include NSMES cases for which manner of death was determined to be suicide and recorded as suicide on the Medical Certificate of Death by the Medical Examiner.   Data for recent months and for the previous year are preliminary and counts and associated rates are likely to increase as case investigations are completed. Case review found that >90% of suicide deaths excluding those caused by drug toxicity were certified post-autopsy, which occurs within days of a reported death. Acccordingly, monitoring of suicide excluding drug toxicity provides a largely accurate, timely indicator of non-drug toxicity suicide. As such, counts of deaths by suicide excluding drug toxicity deaths is provided in addition to counts of total suicide deaths. Indicators of probable and confirmed drug toxicity deaths (including accident and suicide deaths) are also available on the data.novascotia.ca site for concurrent monitoring.  Data provided here may differ from Vital Statistics data sources due to differences in reporting timeframes (e.g. a death certified as suicide may appear under the 'not elsewhere classified' classification if the death was not certified by the time of data submission for a particular report.  Geocoding of address data has resulted in reclassification of zone of residence for a small number of cases (compared to prior releases of data). resource.name: Marriage Bonds 1763-1864; Marriage Registrations 1864-1946
resource.description: Civil registration of marriages in Nova Scotia began in 1758, with the introduction of procedures for obtaining a marriage license. The license was optional, surviving records are incomplete, and 'calling the banns' remained the preferred procedure for formalizing the marriage ritual. The parallel custom of posting a Marriage Bond, in addition to taking out a license, also dates from this early period. The bond was an optional adjunct which served to indicate the absence of legal impediments to the intended marriage; an incomplete series of these bonds exists for the years 1763-1864. Mandatory civil registration of marriages began in 1864 and has continued since, although compliance was not universal throughout the province until the early 20th century.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Minimum Wage
resource.description: Provincial regulations establish the province’s minimum wage. Minimum wage is the lowest legal wage employers can pay their employees. This dataset includes minimum wage rates in Nova Scotia dating back to 2002. Employers, employees and the public request minimum wage data, including in relation to historical rates.

domain_metadata.value: Between 1958 and 1965, minimum wage was set at a weekly - rather than hourly - rate and was based on where the work was performed (provincial zones). From 1965 to 1971, hourly minimum wages rates were set based on age, experience, sex and provincial zones. From 1972 until 1992 hourly minimum wage rates were set based on age and experience. Starting in 1993, age was removed as a factor in setting the minimum wage, which resulted in experienced and inexperienced rates being set until  April 1, 2020 when the inexperienced rate was eliminated leaving just one minimum wage rate.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Examination Results by year and board - Français 10
resource.description: Provides examination results for Reading (scaled score and performance level) and Writing (performance level for four components of writing) for each year examination has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the examinations.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of July 28, 2021. Assessments were not administered for 2016-2017 school year. French (CSAP) program students enrolled in Français 10 courses write this examination in January or June. French Immersion students do not write this examination.  For the reading portion, students read different types of texts and answered questions about what they read. Students also completed two writing tasks. Student performance in writing was reported for the four components: Ideas, Organization, Language Use and Conventions. Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) Level 4 (above the expectation). Students also received a scaled score in reading (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800). Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to develop this examination and to set the expectation of the examination. The expectation is what students should know and be able to do at the end of the course. As of April 1, 2018, Nova Scotia Regional School Boards became Regional Centres for Education (RCE). Geographical areas for regional centres and their historical school boards can be found here: https://novascotia.ca/just/regulations/regs/edregcen.htm . The Conseil scolaire acadien provincial (CSAP) remained the same.

resource.name: NS Provincial Gaming Activity
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Alcohol, Gaming, Fuel and Tobacco Division is responsible for the regulation of legal gaming in the province of Nova Scotia.  These gaming activities include:
i.             Atlantic Lottery Corporation products (ALC), 
ii.            Casino Nova Scotia (Casino),
iii.           charitable bingo (Bingo),
iv.           charitable ticket lotteries (Lotteries), and 
v.            video lottery terminals (VLT).

domain_metadata.value: This information is reported in the Annual Gaming Report prepared by the Alcohol, Gaming, Fuel and Tobacco Division of Service Nova Scotia, and posted on the AGFT website at http://novascotia.ca/sns/access/alcohol-gaming/publications.asp

For the purpose of measuring the volume of gaming activities on a consistent basis, the Alcohol, Gaming, Fuel and Tobacco Division uses the “wager” as a base unit, presented in thousands of dollars ($ thousands).  This figure represents the amount of money (rounded to the nearest  thousand dollar)  actually wagered on each gaming activity before prizes are awarded, operating expenses are deducted, and other assorted expenditures are accounted for.  The wager for each type of gaming activity is defined in the following manner: cash deposited when referring to VLTs; cash deposited and value of tickets inserted into casino slot machines plus the chips purchased for table games when referring to casinos; cash paid for the purchase of bingo cards when referring to bingo; and cash paid for the purchase of tickets when referring to ticket lotteries. In October 2023, erroneous 2021-22 fiscal year casino figures (Casino Total and Prizes) were updated in the dataset. Discrepancy between the public dataset and the 2021-22 Gaming Report figures will be addressed in the 2022-23 report.

resource.name: NS Correctional Services Expenditures
resource.description: The financial expenditures of Correctional Services is an indicator of the resources required to administer custodial and community-based sentences in the province. This dataset provides financial information such as the gross expenditures on Nova Scotia Corrections; the per capita expenditures on Nova Scotia Corrections, which is calculated using the total population in Nova Scotia; and the average daily cost in adult custody in Nova Scotia, which is calculated using the adult offender population in adult facilities. Fluctuations in the cost of Corrections may be driven by a number of factors, including but not limited to: the level of crime, legislative and policy responses to crime, sentencing practices, and administrative changes relating to organizational structure and the delivery of services, as well as changes in salaries and benefits for staff. The source for the financial information is the Nova Scotia Department of Justice, Financial Services Corporate Service Unit (CSU). Population data is sourced from Statistics Canada CANSIM Table 051-0005 - Estimates of population, Canada, provinces and territories.

resource.name: Ecological Land Classification (ELC) - 2015
resource.description: The Ecological Land Classification (ELC version 2015) for Nova Scotia provides a hierarchical mapping of the province's forest ecosystems into ecosections, ecodistricts and ecoregions. It includes interpretation of the dominant natural disturbance regimes and potential climax forests at the ecosection level.

domain_metadata.value: The Department of Natural Resources and Renewables has prepared the 2015 version of the ELC to assist in the planning and management of sustainable forests. In this framework of mapped ecosystems the ELC provides an understanding of ecosystem form and function and the dependent biodiversity by linking the physical and biological environment of each system. Ecosystems on the landscape represent the effects of the interactions of climate, landform, water and soils and thus the distribution of biodiversity. Land Systems are mapped at 1:50,000 from the Nova Scotia Biophysical Land Classification were used to define the physical attributes of the smallest mapped unit of the ELC - the Ecosection (1:50,000). Infrared aerial photography (1:63,560) flown in 1976 and used to determine the Land Systems was also used to re-check Ecosection boundaries. In addition the following were used to assist in the delineation of Ecosections, Ecodistricts and Ecoregions: Provincial soils maps - 1:50,000; 1:63,000; 1:126,000 Surficial geology maps - 1:500,000; 1:100,000 National topographic series - 1:50,000 Forestry mapping - 1:10,000 Geology - 1:640,000 Radarsat 3D imagery The Climate for Agriculture in Canada (1985) The Natural History of Nova Scotia (1996) Geological Background and Physiography of Nova Scotia (1982) A National Ecological Framework for Canada (1995) Ecoregions and Ecodistricts of Nova Scotia (1999) Natural Landscapes of Nova Scotia (1997) This edition includes updates of the 2005 and 2007 editions to incorporate more recent data and understanding as of 2015.
Based on data available and understanding as of 2015

resource.name: Index for Regional "Innovation-Driven Entrepreneurship" (IDE)
resource.description: The dataset provides indicators for assessing “innovation-driven entrepreneurship’ in regional ecosystems (iEcosystems) based on Nova Scotia’s Functional Economic Regions. Each indicator includes a score of 1 to 10 on how a region performs against other regions across Canada. The data fields include:  Index Year, Functional Economic Region Name, Indicator, and Score. Indicators are subject to change over time.

domain_metadata.value: For each indicator, every functional economic region in Nova Scotia was ranked against other regions across Canada and provided with a score from 1 to 10 based on a even distribution.  No weighting has been assigned to any indicator.
Calculated in 2021 using the most recent available data at the time that covered the 2016 to 2021 period.

resource.name: Invest Nova Scotia Venture Capital Investments
resource.description:
Invest Nova Scotia is Nova Scotia’s business development agency that works to promote economic growth and community economic development in the province by enabling business, innovation, sustainability and entrepreneurship. 

Early stage deep technology start-ups are a key focus area for Invest Nova Scotia. They are supported through venture capital, incubation facilities, expert advice, and other acceleration initiatives.

Invest Nova Scotia makes equity investments through the Nova Scotia First Fund (NSFF), a venture capital fund backed by the Nova Scotia government. Venture capital-backed start-ups typically have a greater economic impact than their non-backed peers, demonstrating stronger growth in revenue, employment and assets. Invest Nova Scotia is driven by generating financial returns on its fund, and also seeks to leverage its deals with other venture capital and angel co-investors, attracting new capital and expertise for the region.

This dataset lists the companies Invest Nova Scotia invested in and the amount invested.

resource.name: Invest Nova Scotia Incubation Resident Companies
resource.description:
Invest Nova Scotia is Nova Scotia’s business development agency that works to promote economic growth and community economic development in the province by enabling business, innovation, sustainability and entrepreneurship. 

Early stage deep technology start-ups are a key focus area for Invest Nova Scotia. They are supported through venture capital, incubation facilities, expert advice, and other acceleration initiatives.

The Bays at Invest Nova Scotia in Dartmouth targets companies in clean technology and a variety of other knowledge-based sectors, and offers a reliable enterprise-grade voice and data network, redundant high-speed internet services, and a dependable server hosting facility. The Labs at Invest Nova Scotia in Halifax focuses on companies in the life sciences industry and offers specialized scientific infrastructure otherwise unavailable in the commercial real estate market. The Start-Up Yard incubation facility at the Centre for Ocean Ventures & Entrepreneurship (COVE) helps early stage companies commercialize their ocean technologies and succeed in the global marketplace.

This dataset lists the resident companies at Invest Nova Scotia’s three incubation facilities.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of June 9, 2023. Some of Invest Nova Scotia's incubation resident companies take space at the facilities for just a short time (i.e., six-months) as their residency is part of an Invest Nova Scotia program (e.g., Start-Up Visa Program, Accelerate Program).

resource.name: Citizenship of Nominees
resource.description:
The Department of Labour, Skills and Immigration (LSI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Applicants are attracted to the Nova Scotia Nominee Program from around the world. This dataset provides the number of nomination certificates issued annually by citizenship of the applicant. 

The maximum number of nomination certificates that LSI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of Feb 3, 2023. A nomination by the Province of Nova Scotia does not guarantee that the applicant will become a permanent resident. The federal government has the final decision on who receives permanent residency and is admissible to Canada based on various considerations that include, but are not limited to, health, criminality and security checks.

resource.name: Queens County Water Quality Data
resource.description: Oceanographic data from sensor strings deployed in Queens County as part of the Centre for Marine Applied Research's (CMAR) Coastal Monitoring Program.
columns_description: parameter measured (Temperature, Dissolved Oxygen, or Salinity)
timestamp of the measurement (in UTC)
value of the measurement (units are noted in UNITS column)
the unit of measurement for corresponding VALUE
model and serial number of the sensor that recorded the measurement
longitude at which the string was deployed (decimal degrees)
if the string was deployed on an aquaculture lease area, the lease number (NA otherwise)
area where the string was deployed
indicates whether the string was attached to a fixed (does not move vertically with the tide) or floating mooring
waterbody in which the string was deployed
latitude at which the string was deployed (decimal degrees)
the deployment and retrieval dates
approximate depth of the sensor below the surface in metres (as measured at low tide for fixed moorings)

domain_metadata.value: Chart (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Queens-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average-Val/twbe-dv9i) and Coastal Monitoring Program Report: Queens County (https://cmar.ca/reports/)

The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) measures essential ocean variables throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters as part of the Coastal Monitoring Program. This program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in 2012 and CMAR became involved in 2017. CMAR collects water quality data (temperature, dissolved oxygen, and intermittent salinity) using autonomous sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or dragging.  The Coastal Monitoring Program data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the WATERBODY, STATION, DEPTH, VARIABLE, and/or TIMESTAMP of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Queens-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average-Val/twbe-dv9i). Water Quality Data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/reports/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server through the Canadian Integrated Ocean Observing System (CIOOS) platform (https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset?q=cmar). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses.  A note on units: For Halifax and Lunenburg counties, dissolved oxygen was measured in units of percent saturation or mg/L, depending on the sensor. For all other counties, dissolved oxygen was measured in units of percent saturation. Measurements in mg/L were corrected for salinity using the Garcia-Gordon (1992) salinity correction factor with a salinity value of 30.6 practical salinity units (based on available data for the region). This correction factor is not required for values recorded in percent saturation. Please contact info@cmar.ca for more information.  If you have accessed any of the Coastal Monitoring Program data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

resource.name: Film Industry Tax Credit – Approved Tax Credits
resource.description: Public record for the Film Industry Tax Credit containing information from approved Part A and Part B applications across all corporations. Information includes company name, parent company name, production title, application type (Part A or B), amount of credit provided (or sought if Part A), approval date.
columns_name:
Amount of Credit Provided 
(or Sought if Part A)

domain_metadata.value: The Film Industry Tax Credit is phased out so this dataset switched to one-time in August 2023. Productions are added to the list after a Part A / Part B application is approved. Part A applications, which are not mandatory, determine whether a production is eligible for the tax credit and uses the production's budget to calculate an estimated tax credit amount the corporation may receive. Part B applications are mandatory and determine whether a production is eligible for the tax credit and uses actual spending to calculate a tax credit amount. Once a Part B application is approved, a tax credit certificate is issued and the corporation can claim the tax credit on their corporate income tax return. The Film Industry Tax Credit has been replaced by the Digital Animation Tax Credit and the Nova Scotia Film & Television Production Incentive Fund.

domain_metadata.value: Understanding Climate Change Impacts in Relation to Wellbeing for Nova Scotia, available at https://climatechange.novascotia.ca/climate-impacts

The projections include 88 individual climate indices for each region, with results presented for two emissions scenarios (RCP4.5 and RCP8.5), four averaged 30-year time periods (1981-2010, 2015-2045, 2035-2065, and 2065-2095, denoted in the data by their end year), and three different percentiles for each to show the model range (p05, p50, and p95). For example, the column "rcp45 p05 2010" displays results for the RCP4.5 scenario, for the fifth percentile (p05) of the multi-model ensemble, for the 1981-2010 time period. This information was generated through an ensemble of 27 climate models as part of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC)’s Coupled Model Intercomparison Project 5 (CMIP5), with the data statistically downscaled for Canada by the Pacific Climate Impacts Consortium (PCIC) using the BCCAQv2 method (downloaded from https://data.pacificclimate.org/portal/downscaled_gcms/map/ in December 2019), with index calculations completed using the Climpact2 tool on behalf of the Province of Nova Scotia. Full methodology, including the list of the 27 models used and additional details on climate indices, can be found in Appendix B of the 2022 Nova Scotia climate change risk assessment report: http://climatechange.novascotia.ca

resource.name: Nova Scotia Assessment Results by Year and Board - Mathématiques en 8e année
resource.description: Provides assessment results for Mathematics (scaled score and performance level) for each year assessment has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the assessments.

domain_metadata.value: French program (CSAP) Grade 8 students write this assessment in June. Students answered questions in each of the mathematics strands (le nombre; les régularités et les relations; la mesure et la géométrie; et les statistiques et les probabilités). Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) and Level 4 (above the expectation).Students also received a scaled score in mathematics (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800).  Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to develop this assessment and to set the performance expectation, which is what students should know and be able to do on their own at the end of grade 8. As of April 1, 2018, Nova Scotia Regional School Boards became Regional Centres for Education (RCE). Geographical areas for regional centres and their historical school boards can be found here: https://novascotia.ca/just/regulations/regs/edregcen.htm . The Conseil scolaire acadien provincial (CSAP) remained the same.

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) coordinates an extensive Coastal Monitoring Program to measure essential ocean variables (EOVs) throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters. This dataset includes data from the Current branch of the program. Data from the Water Quality and Wave branches of the program are also available on the Nova Scotia Open Data Portal. CMAR has worked with the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) and marine service providers to measure ocean current at various locations in Nova Scotia since 2007. The data is collected with Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) deployed on the seafloor. An ADCP is a hydroacoustic current meter that measures water velocities over a range of depths. These sensors measure soundwaves scattered back from moving particles in the water column and use the Doppler effect to estimate speed and direction.  Current data is organized by county. Each county dataset includes data from multiple ADCP deployments that vary in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when analyzing the data. The “Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information” dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha) summarises the specifications of each deployment. Individual deployments are identified in the county dataset and metadata by a unique ID in the deployment_id column.   The county datasets are large and can exceed the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the waterbody, station, and/or deployment_id of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/e9p6-as65).   Current data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Current Data: Deployment Information" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/rs2e-ekha). Summary reports for each county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. Data have been trimmed of side-lobe interference. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. CMAR recommends users apply additional quality control prior to using the data. If you have accessed any of the Current data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability, and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The station location dataset (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/dhns-eqjr) contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique Deployment ID which can be used to filter and separate individual datasets for export from the Open Data Portal. Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs), Xeos wind-wave buoys, and MarineLabs wind-wave buoys consist of time-series measurements of significant wave height, wave period, and average wave direction. Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. Note that some observations of 0m wave height may reflect false zero recordings, and analyses should be conducted accordingly. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the ADCPs presents wave height (significant, maximum, height average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in metres, and period (peak, maximum, period average of the top 1/3 & 1/10 largest waves) measured in seconds. Each individual row of data (Ensemble) from the wind-wave buoys presents wave height (significant, maximum) in metres and average wave direction in degrees relative to true north, corrected for localized magnetic declination specific to the deployment coordinates. The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements) can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment. Date and time data are in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC).

resource.name: Amount Raised by Invest Nova Scotia Investment Portfolio Companies
resource.description:
Invest Nova Scotia is Nova Scotia’s business development agency that works to promote economic growth and community economic development in the province by enabling business, innovation, sustainability and entrepreneurship. 

Early stage deep technology start-ups are a key focus area for Invest Nova Scotia. They are supported through venture capital, incubation facilities, expert advice, and other acceleration initiatives.

Invest Nova Scotia makes equity investments through the Nova Scotia First Fund (NSFF), a venture capital fund backed by the Nova Scotia government. Venture capital-backed start-ups typically have a greater economic impact than their non-backed peers, demonstrating stronger growth in revenue, employment and assets. Invest Nova Scotia is driven by generating financial returns on its fund, and also seeks to leverage its deals with other venture capital and angel co-investors, attracting new capital and expertise for the region.

The Amount Raised by Invest Nova Scotia Investment Portfolio Companies dataset shows the total investment dollars raised by Invest Nova Scotia’s investment portfolio throughout the year. The amount speaks to the strength of the companies in Invest Nova Scotia’s portfolio (i.e., their ability to attract capital) and Invest Nova Scotia’s ability to support them in those efforts.
columns_name: Amount raised by Innovacorp portfolio compaies

resource.name: Hand Hygiene – Hand Washing Rates for Healthcare Workers
resource.description: Hand Hygiene rates represents the hand washing rates for healthcare workers within the Nova Scotia Health Authority and the IWK.  The rates are collected and reported to quarterly by hygiene auditors who are trained hospital staff.  The rates for healthcare workers who clean their hands before initial contact with a patient and/or patient environment and the rates for after contact with the patient and/or patient environment are reported publicly and included in this dataset. Proper hand hygiene is one of the most important means to preventing the spread of germs which can cause infections. This dataset lists the hand hygiene rates that are reported publicly by the Department of Health and Wellness. Data fields include: Year, Quarter, Zone, Before Initial Contact, After Contact.

resource.name: Victoria County Water Quality Data
resource.description: Oceanographic data from sensor strings deployed in Victoria County as part of the Centre for Marine Applied Research's (CMAR) Coastal Monitoring Program.

domain_metadata.value: Chart (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Victoria-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average-V/chb4-suz2) and Coastal Monitoring Program Report: Victoria County (https://cmar.ca/reports/)

The Centre for Marine Applied Research (CMAR) measures essential ocean variables throughout Nova Scotia’s coastal waters as part of the Coastal Monitoring Program. This program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in 2012 and CMAR became involved in 2017. CMAR collects water quality data (temperature, dissolved oxygen, and intermittent salinity) using autonomous sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or dragging. The Coastal Monitoring Program data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends using the filter options of the Open Data Portal to filter to the WATERBODY, STATION, DEPTH, VARIABLE, and/or TIMESTAMP of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Victoria-County-Water-Quality-Data-Daily-Average-V/chb4-suz2). Water Quality Data for other Nova Scotia counties is also available through the Open Data Portal. The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on the Portal shows locations with available data (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/reports/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server through the Canadian Integrated Ocean Observing System (CIOOS) platform (https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset?q=cmar). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. Some data are excluded from the final dataset during quality control processes. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. A note on units: For Halifax and Lunenburg counties, dissolved oxygen was measured in units of percent saturation or mg/L, depending on the sensor. For all other counties, dissolved oxygen was measured in units of percent saturation. Measurements in mg/L were corrected for salinity using the Garcia-Gordon (1992) salinity correction factor with a salinity value of 30.6 practical salinity units (based on available data for the region). This correction factor is not required for values recorded in percent saturation. Please contact info@cmar.ca for more information. If you have accessed any of the Coastal Monitoring Program data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback through this quick questionnaire (https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform). Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data.

domain_metadata.value: Understanding Climate Change Impacts in Relation to Wellbeing for Nova Scotia, available at https://climatechange.novascotia.ca/climate-impacts

Sea level rise projections for the province of Nova Scotia and its 18 individual census divisions (counties). Results are presented for two emissions scenarios (RCP4.5 and RCP8.5), four time periods (1981-2010, 2015-2045, 2035-2065, and 2065-2095), and three different percentiles for each to show the model range (p05, p50, and p95). The time periods were calculated by fitting a linear trend to the 31-year periods and taking the average, so 2065-2095 equates to the expected SLR in 2080 (representing the middle year of each time period). The maximum, mean, and minimum values for each region represent the statistics for different locations within each county (e.g., for Annapolis, looking at RCP8.5 p50 in 2080, anticipated sea level rise is between 55.7-58.3 cm depending where in the county you are). Sea level rise projections were developed for Canada by James et al. (Geological Survey of Canada, 2021, Open File 8764). This information incorporates the most recent sea level projections from IPCC AR5 (Church et al., 2013a) which includes contributions from glaciers and thermo-steric expansion of the ocean. The local contributions to sea level rise associated with glacial isostatic adjustment were updated with the NAD83v70VG vertical land motion (Robin et al., 2020).  Sea level projections are relative to the average sea level over the base period 1986-2005. Full methodology can be found in Appendix B of the 2022 Nova Scotia climate change risk assessment report: http://climatechange.novascotia.ca

resource.name: Nova Scotia Topographic DataBase - Buildings (Poly Layer)
resource.description:
Part of the Nova Scotia Topographic Database (NSTDB), the buildings theme layer is updated and maintained from aerial photography. Buildings over 30m (one side) are collected as polygons, all others as points. Selected buildings are inspected in the field or interpreted from aerial photography and classified according to use such as hospitals, schools, police stations or community centres. Building feature codes and their descriptions are provided with the download in a NSTDB feature code table.
Data download also available via GeoNova: https://nsgi.novascotia.ca/WSF_DDS/DDS.svc/DownloadFile?tkey=fhrTtdnDvfytwLz6&id=20

Select Nova Scotia is a program developed by the Province of Nova Scotia to encourage Nova Scotians to shop and buy locally. Select Nova Scotia promotions and campaigns and the web site raise consumer awareness about Nova Scotia agri-food and seafood products, and other locally made goods.

domain_metadata.value: Archived on May 27, 2022. The Select Nova Scotia program has ended and the data contained in this dataset is no longer being collected. Much of the information is from businesses that have registered, self-identified as producers and sellers of local food, craft and artisan products.  However, the orignial web site was populated from an existing database. Some errors and inaccuracies are still present in both the old dataset and newly registered. If businesses are not diligent about updating their profile, errors may exist.  We will be requiring all current members to update their profile yearly, and will be removing profiles that do not meet our newly instated web site guidelines: To be eligible to register on the Select Nova Scotia website, your business must: have its head office in Nova Scotia; produce, harvest or sell Nova Scotia products; if a restaurant, be a member in good standing of Taste of Nova Scotia.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Assessment Results by Year and Board - Reading and Writing in Grade 8
resource.description: Provides assessment results for Reading (scaled score and performance level) and Writing (performance level for four components of writing) for each year assessment has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the assessments.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of July 28, 2021. Assessments were not administered for 2016-2017 school year. English program Grade 8 students, including French Immersion, write this assessment in June. For the reading portion of the assessment, students read different types of texts and answered questions about what they read. For the writing portion of the assessment, students completed two writing tasks. Student performance in writing was reported for the four components: Ideas, Organization, Language Use and Conventions. Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) Level 4 (above the expectation). Students also received a scaled score in reading (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800). Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to build this assessment, score the writing tasks and set the performance expectations in Reading and Writing. The expectation is what students should know and be able to do on their own at the end of grade 8. As of April 1, 2018, Nova Scotia Regional School Boards became Regional Centres for Education (RCE). Geographical areas for regional centres and their historical school boards can be found here: https://novascotia.ca/just/regulations/regs/edregcen.htm . The Conseil scolaire acadien provincial (CSAP) remained the same.

domain_metadata.value: The counters add up each person who walks past, which means the numbers do not represent unique visitation. The numbers in the data represent the totals for each month. resource.name: Events East Group Economic Impact

domain_metadata.value: Current as of October 25, 2023. All direct expenditures associated with Halifax Convention Centre are considered incremental. 27 per cent of Scotiabank Centre direct expenditures are incremental. Where there are missing values, the data is not available. With the transition to a new governance structure combined with operating both the World Trade and Convention Centre (WTCC) and the new Halifax Convention Centre during the fiscal year, 2017-18 represents an anomaly for the organization and is not comparable to past operations or indicative of future years. Events East Group began managing all operations of the former Trade Centre Limited (TCL) effective April 1, 2017, however, the financial cutover to Events East was triggered by achievement of substantial completion of the Halifax Convention Centre, which did not take place until March 1, 2018. For this reason, comparatives between Halifax Convention Centre and Convention Centre are not applicable.

columns_description: Quality control flag for temperature. Maximum flag value from three automated quality control tests: grossrange,  spike, and rolling_sd. Flag values can be:  "Pass",  "Not Evaluated", "Suspect/Of Interest", or "Fail"

domain_metadata.value: The Centre for Marine Applied Research’s (CMAR) Coastal Monitoring Program provides high resolution data on ocean variables from around the coast of Nova Scotia. The program was initiated by the Nova Scotia Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture in the early 1990s. In 2019, CMAR assumed responsibility for the program and expanded its scope and mandate. Through the Water Quality Branch of the program, CMAR collects temperature, dissolved oxygen, and salinity data using sensors deployed on “sensor strings”. A sensor string typically consists of a line anchored to the sea floor by an acoustic release and suspended by a sub-surface buoy, with sensors attached at various depths below the surface (as measured at low tide). Alternatively, a string may be attached to surface moorings, including floating docks, buoys, and equipment. Sensor strings are deployed for several months, and data are measured every 1 minute to 1 hour. Sensors are retrieved for data offload by triggering the acoustic release when applicable, by directly removing from surface moorings, or occasionally by divers or grappling methods. Automated Quality Control tests have been applied to the data to identify outlying and unexpected observations. The results of these tests are summarized in the “qc_flag” columns of the dataset. Each data point is assigned a flag value of “Pass”, “Suspect/Of Interest”, “Fail”, or “Not Evaluated”. Observations flagged as “Pass” passed all tests and can be included in analyses. Dissolved oxygen observations flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” likely indicate biofouling signals and should be excluded from analysis or used with extreme caution. Observations for other variables flagged as “Suspect/Of Interest” should be reviewed before being included in analyses. Observations flagged as “Fail” should be excluded from most analyses. Some tests cannot be applied to certain observations, which will be flagged as “Not Evaluated”. These observations can typically be included in analyses. Flags should be used as a guide only, and data users are responsible for evaluating the quality of the data prior to use in any analysis. For more information about the Quality Control tests, visit the CMAR Data Governance website (https://dempsey-cmar.github.io/cmp-data-governance/pages/cmp_about.html). The Coastal Monitoring Program Water Quality data is organized by county. These datasets are very large, typically exceeding the number of rows that can be viewed in Excel. CMAR recommends filtering the data to the waterbody, station, depth, quality control flag, and/or time period of interest before exporting. A chart derived from the dataset also allows for interactive filtering and export (https://data.novascotia.ca/d/5p9y-iyag). The "Nova Scotia Water Quality Data: Station Locations" dataset on this Portal shows additional locations with available Water Quality data collected through CMAR’s Coastal Monitoring Program (https://data.novascotia.ca/Nature-and-Environment/Coastal-Monitoring-Program-Station-Locations/cjfb-f4d4). Summary reports by county are available on the CMAR website (https://cmar.ca/coastal-monitoring-program/). Data can also be downloaded from the ERDAPP server through the Canadian Integrated Ocean Observing System (CIOOS) platform (https://catalogue.cioosatlantic.ca/dataset?q=cmar). Data collection and retrieval are ongoing. The datasets and reports may be revised pending ongoing data collection and analyses. If you have accessed any Coastal Monitoring Program data, CMAR would appreciate your feedback: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSe3TD6umrsVVKnQL13VVMJIpckCi2ctONJsgN7_g-4c-tKTuw/viewform. Please acknowledge the Centre for Marine Applied Research in any published material that uses this data. Contact info@cmar.ca for more information.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Lake Chemistry Data
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Lake Survey program is a partnership initiative between the Department of Environment and Climate Change and the Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture to inventory lakes throughout the province determining baseline water quality, in support of both sport fisheries and water resource management areas.

The following weblink connects to a Department of Environment and Climate Change web map that includes the locations of the monitored lakes within the province and an alternative method for downloading the same lake chemistry dataset: http://nse.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=7ded7a30bef44f848e8a4fc8672c89bd"

domain_tags: lakes; water bodies; chemistry; water resources management; fish; water quality

domain_metadata.value: Water quality samples are collected at approximately 10 different lakes per annum. The samples are submitted to the Nova Scotia Environmental Services Laboratory operated by the Nova Scotia Health Authority in Halifax, NS for analysis. Field parameters are measured using a multiparameter instrument. The following are the monitored water quality parameters and applicable measurement units: field temperature (°C), field dissolved oxygen (mg/L), Secchi disc depth (m), select metals (µg/L), calcium (mg/L), magnesium (mg/L), hardness as CaCO3 (mg/L), lab conductivity (umho/cm), lab pH (-), lab turbidity (-), alkalinity as CaCO3 (mg/L), chloride (mg/L), colour (TCU), silica (mg/L), sulphate (mg/L), total nitrogen (mg/L), nitrate and nitrite as N (mg/L), ammonia as N (mg/L), orthophosphorus as P, (mg/L), total phosphorus (mg/L), total suspended solids (mg/L), total organic carbon (mg/L), chlorophyll a (mg/m3) and pheophytin (µg/L).  Bathymetric maps have been produced for most of the sampled lakes and their attributes (surface area, volume, max & mean depths) are included in the dataset.
